Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).raw_text: Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000) (recognizing parental rights and that parental decisionmaking is to be accorded weight in custody/visitation matters).
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).proposition: Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000) (recognizing parental rights and that parental decisionmaking is to be accorded weight in custody/visitation matters).
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely recognizes a fundamental constitutional right of parents to make decisions concerning the care, custody, and control of their children and holds that courts must give “special weight” to a fit parent’s determinations in visitation disputes. It invalidates Washington’s nonparental visitation order in part because the trial court failed to accord any deference to the mother’s decision about grandparent visitation. This directly supports the proposition that Troxel recognizes parental rights and that parental decisionmaking must be accorded weight in custody/visitation matters.
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “In light of this extensive precedent, it cannot now be doubted that the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment protects the fundamental right of parents to make decisions concerning the care, custody, and control of their children. … The problem here is not that the Washington Superior Court intervened, but that when it did so, it gave no special weight at all to Granville's determination of her daughters' best interests. … [I]f a fit parent's decision of the kind at issue here becomes subject to judicial review, the court must accord at least some special weight to the parent's own determination.”
